# ðŸŽ¬ Netflix Data Analysis

This report explores the Netflix dataset: movies and TV shows, their distribution by year, country, and genre.

---

## ðŸ“‚ Load libraries & dataset

```{r setup, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(plotly)
library(sqldf)

# Load dataset
netflix <- read.csv("../data/netflix_titles.csv")

# Quick overview
str(netflix)
summary(netflix)

## ðŸ“Š Movies vs TV Shows

netflix %>%
  count(type) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = type, y = n, fill = type)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  labs(title = "Movies vs TV Shows on Netflix",
       x = "Type", y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal()


## ðŸ“ˆ Releases over time

netflix %>%
  group_by(release_year) %>%
  summarise(count = n()) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = release_year, y = count)) +
  geom_line(color = "red") +
  labs(title = "Number of Releases Over Time",
       x = "Release Year", y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal()


## ðŸŽ­ Top Genres

# Split genres (listed_in column)
genres <- netflix %>%
  separate_rows(listed_in, sep = ", ") %>%
  count(listed_in, sort = TRUE)

head(genres, 10)

genres %>%
  slice_max(n, n = 10) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = reorder(listed_in, n), y = n)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "steelblue") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title = "Top 10 Genres on Netflix",
       x = "Genre", y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal()


## ðŸŒ Top Countries

netflix %>%
  filter(!is.na(country)) %>%
  count(country, sort = TRUE) %>%
  slice_max(n, n = 10) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = reorder(country, n), y = n)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "darkgreen") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title = "Top 10 Countries on Netflix",
       x = "Country", y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal()
